newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslavia seen importing 300,000 tonnes of wheat.
newsitem.headline: Yugoslavia seen importing 300,000 tonnes of wheat.

text.p: BELGRADE, Nov 27 (Reuter) _ Yugoslavia will import about 300,000 tonnes of wheat for domestic needs, a source close to the government said on Wednesday.
"We will not have enough wheat till the next year's harvest," the government source told Reuters. "We are forced to import about 300,000 tonnes to meet domestic market needs."
Belgrade newspapers earlier this week said the government would meet on Thursday to discuss an import quota for wheat.
According to the government statistics office, the 1996 wheat harvest dropped to a 25-year low of 1.72 million tonnes, down from 2.97 million in 1995.
Yields were at their lowest since 1972, falling to 2.96 tonnes per hectare from 3.4 tonnes the previous year.
Yugoslavia, comprising Serbia and Montenegro, reduced its wheat area in 1995 by 300,000 hectares to 582,965.
Reduced area, bad weather and a lack of fuel and fertiliser were the main reasons for the fall in output.
Wheat sowing has been completed on about 820,000 hectares out of 850,000 hectares planned this year, the source said.
"We expect next year to produce enough to export about one million tonnes of wheat," the source said.
